Award.AwardTitle: Cybersecurity Laboratory: Enhancing the Hands-on Experience in Cybersecurity Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Cyber Service: Scholarship for Service (SFS) capacity building project at the Stevens Institute of Technology is developing a laboratory and related learning materials that explore the role and use of clustered graphical processing units (GPUs) in cybersecurity applications and education. The existing cybersecurity laboratory at Stevens is being upgraded to include clusters of NVIDIA S1070 and S2050 GPUs. Instructional modules on multicore computing and cybersecurity are being developed and integrated into undergraduate courses on computer algebra and cryptography. The new laboratory facility is also being used for senior design projects. The course materials in multicore computing are being adopted and evaluated in an undergraduate course at Howard University. The results from this project are being disseminated through conference, including a DIMACS workshop, and journal publications. The project includes rigorous formative and summative evaluation plans with both qualitative and quantitative components coordinated by an experienced independent evaluator.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has resulted in four main outcomes:

  1. Improvement of the cybersecurity laboratory infrastructure to include multi-/many-core equipment.  The laboratory is used for various educational purposes---including teaching of hands-on cybersecurity courses as part of the various cybersecurity curricula offered at the recipient institution, student projects, and extra-curricular activities such as participation in competitions. 
  2. Enabling cutting-edge research in multi-/many-core computing in cryptography which led to various publications in the area of parallel lattice basis reduction algorithms.
  3. Development of three modules on many-/multi-core computing (sorting, vector/matrix operations/graph algorithms, cryptography). Each module includes presentation slides, instructor notes, as well as sample questions with suggested solutions and grading rubrics. The modules are designed such that they can be integrated into a variety of courses including courses on algorithms, discrete mathematics, computer algebra, cybersecurity, or cryptography. All modules are taught in the context of a number of courses (at the undergraduate and graduate levels) at the recipient institution. Howard University (an HBCU) served as a first adopter when the modules were first developed. The materials are available to the community at large and may be obtained through http://www.stevens.edu/ses/cassia/resources.
  4. Workshop on Multi-core and Cryptography---organized in collaboration with the Center for Discrete Mathematics and Theoretical Computer Science (DIMACS)---which was founded as an NSF Science and Technology Center. The workshop was geared to explore and advance the state-of-the-art of multi-/many-core computing in cryptography in theory, practice, and education. The program (which included both invited talks/tutorials as well as contributed talks) was compiled to bridge across the disciplines and bring together researchers and educators from both parallel computing and cybersecurity.  The workshop attracted a diverse group of 40+ attendees including senior/junior researchers and faculty, as well as undergraduate and graduate students. Details on the workshop can be found at http://dimacs.rutgers.edu/Workshops/Multicore/.
